greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The differences 1-1, 21-12, 321-123, ..., 10987654321-12345678910, 1110987654321-1234567891011, etc.
comment: All terms are divisible by 9, cf. A083449. There is an increasingly longer subsequence of negative terms starting at each power of 10, namely for indices n = 10..12, 100..123, 1000..1234, etc. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 02 2016
reference: S. S. Gupta, Unique Numbers, Science Today, Jan 01 1988, India.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..350
maple: u:= proc(n) u(n):= `if`(n=1, 1, parse(cat(u(n-1), n))) end:
d:= proc(n) d(n):= `if`(n=1, 1, parse(cat(n, d(n-1)))) end:
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[ {a = "", k = 1}, While[k < n + 1, a = StringJoin[ ToString[k], a]; k++ ]; Return[ ToExpression[a] - ToExpression[ StringReverse[a]]]]; Table[ f[n], {n, 1, 17} ]
program: (PARI) apply( {A019566(n)=A000422(n)-A007908(n)}, [1..22]) \\ Replacing code from Jan 13 2013, following a comment from Nov 02 2016. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 07 2020
results.author: _Robert Dickau_
ext: More terms from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jan 11 2002
Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 22 2020
